comments.commentBody:
The opposite of pay-as-you-go is not a system of income redistribution. The opposite of pay-as-you-go is saving now and spending later. Social Security was set up to look like as a save now, spend the savings later program when in reality it is a pay-as-you-go system (with a kitty to smooth over fluctuations in revenue) that takes from the young and gives to the old. My social security premiums went to my folks (who in fact did not need them) and my payments will come from the next generation.

The conservative dream of everyone financing their retirement through their savings is unrealistic. Everyone does not save. But if they did we would still have a problem. Consumer spending would be less because people would be saving. The savings would have to be invested, and the return would be low because the supply of investment would be competing for the relatively scarce investment opportunities available. The return would also be uncertain because bad investments would grow to sop up the available savings, as happened with bundles of home mortgages.

I suppose it is an economist's dream to be waist deep in investment capital, but at the present time much of this capital is parked with Treasury securities that do not even keep up with inflation.

If young people are to keep old folks alive, it is much better to do so directly by paying taxes rather than working so owners can make profits that old folks get in their dividend checks.
McLaren will miss Lewis Hamilton more than Mercedes will miss Schumacher.
Who would even get this stuff! Name a drink after them and call it a day: https://drinkmydrink.com/
With the current impasse over the budget, is there any thought given to stopping EU enlargement since so many of the new countries are in need of large subsidies?

Do you think the UK will end up leaving the EU and would be in their best interest to leave the EU?

USFS estimates that annual tree mortality in the continental US has tripled since 1970. Global warming exacerbated water stress is one reason; ozone pollution from fossil fuel burning is another. Our Western forests are degraded from industrial logging in the last 60 years, causing hotter microclimates and less moisture.

We need to slow our use of wood products, and allow our wrecked forests to adapt to the coming global warming. Many won't, but continuing to chop them down is the worst thing we could be doing.

Of course, we also need to drastically reduce our rate of burning fossil fuels. We could do so, but standing in the way are a group of greedy hillbillies, who have managed to buy Congress and our media. it's up to us to stop them.

That payroll tax cut you propose keeping is lowering the amount that will be calculated later for the individuals Social Security payments.

It was a stupid idea then and is now. Those workers taking home a few dollars more a month now, will pay for it later. conservatives such as Douthat would have retirees get even less than they are now. The GOP has been trying to eliminate SS ever since the act was passed. It was called a Socialist program then, and still is by them. At the time buying securities through a broker was expensive. The stocks were not expensive but the fees were.

The Republicans want you to have 401Ks that are managed by brokerage firms and funds. There is big money to be made by putting the American workers savings in managed retirement accounts. SS does have fees, it is also an insurance policy that will help your kids finish school, your wife will get survivor benefits, it keeps people out of poverty, lowering the costs of helping those who do get it.

When you retire do not leave your savings in the 401K. the management company charges fees. Put it in a self directed IRA account at a discount brokerage. There are no fees, and the broker will help you make selections, but you should educate yourself as to what equities to buy and sell also.

SS has been a life saver for millions, even though many do not get much it is more than they would get without it. Do not fall for the conservative cow waste.
I watched the show too. We need another FDR. For both problems.
Thanks Ken, in your Odyssey.

Rather than having not learned, isn't it a complete lack of political leadership, laziness, and greed? After all, here's a country that produced the Hummer not too long ago, where presidential candidates feel funding for PBS and gay marriage are important topics.

I just finished re-watching Ken Burn's  documentary on the Dust Bowl. The conditions that created those dust storms were man made just as climate change is now, and they were at the time in the midst of an economic crisis.  Having not learned the lessons of either the economic crisis or that altering  the enviorment can lead to huge unintended consequences, we are again on the verge of disaster of epic proportions as we again ignore the possible consequences in search of economic gains.

You may wish to read what Mr Friedman says a bit more carefully. I suspect he would argue that the cycle we see in place is the reactions an d counter reactions of the Israeli Right and Hamas to each other. When Israelis feel insecure, as he points out, they are more likely to support a hawkish approach and Hamas knows that and exploits it. And so it goes. That is surely Mr Friedman's point. To suggest that "Israel" is "fully responsible" is at , best, naive , at worst, partisan.

My response to replies -- Thank you.

Does Israel do these things in response to the rockets of Hamas? Yes. Is this a cycle with two sides? Yes.

Must Israel react in this one way, having no other choices? No.

Israel has overwhelming power, military and financial and backing of outsiders, to take an initiative to get out of the cycle, not to allow Hamas to control events.

The right wing stays in this cycle because they like the excuse. It excuses what they really want, more land instead of possible peace with what they have. Greater Israel. Their dreams are much different than peace now. They won't have peace.

Given what Hamas is doing, they can avoid peace, and two states. What they will get is one state, the last thing they want. It will be democracy, and a good one, but not the religious democracy of which they dream.

You may be right that the right wants to maintain the status quo. One has to be careful in somehow equating Israeli "expansionism" with some quasi imperialist agenda - we're not after all talking about anything akin to the age of empire here.

It would be interesting if you could describe what it would look like for Israel to take the initiative to break the cycle. It is one thing to say that this is possible, but some details would be instructive.

Israel's "permanent death grip on the West Bank, which will be the undoing of the Jewish democracy" is done by Israel because its right wing wants to do that. Nobody "makes them do it." They can't blame the victim or somebody else.

You do nobody any favors by suggesting Israel is not in control of itself and its own actions, fully responsible for the consequences of what it does.
He is winter, come to end the brief flowering.

If we get rid of the payroll tax then we can all spend more money on Black Friday. Instead how about we not shred the safety net even further by making cuts to SSI and instead pare back the defense budget, create a Medicare for all system that will help to bring down health care costs and preserve SSI by raising the income cap. And maybe let the tax rates rise on everyone, including corporate rates, if need be.
I should have said, that is the only penalty. If the review is permissible by rule, it is carried out.

Well thank gosh that Clinton spent so much of his time fraternizing with his political opponents.  Who knows what might have happened if he didn't.  Why, they might  well have impeached him over an indiscretion with a White House intern of all things!  Oh, wait...

It's yet to be decoded that the Egyptian president Mohamed Morsi was genuinely moved to cease-fire mediation, alongwith Obama, between the Hamas and Israel, or viewed it an opportune moment to push his agenda of consolidating his personal hold on power during the constitutional vacuum in Egypt while continuing to receive the US goodwill and largesse. However, by all indications, the latter seems to be the case. Under the circumstances, not only Morsi has emerged a new incarnation of Mubarak, but a willing ally of Netanyahu to keep the Israel-Palestine problem alive, with pushing the two-state solution farther away and keeping the Fatah-Hamas as dividede as before. Not only the Middle East conundrum is likely to turn more complex, but the US too is likely to be dragged deeper into this Middle East quagmire, with no prospects of peace and stability in sight.
Jude may be tired of it, but I found it enormously entertaining.
I hope you are having a nice break, Deb

Debby, thanks!  After I pulled the right side of the window all the way to the right of the screen, I still had to move the window so a large portion of the puzzle was off the left side of the screen before I could see the whole note.  I had figured out the trick by then, but was frustrated because I could only see the first four words of the note.  This is on a Mac.

I was able to solve and get the x-thing without the full note (which was cut off in Across Lite on my macbook air and read "fourteen symmetrically placed answ...). For future reference is there a way to click on something somewhere to get the full note?

It appears to me that there are two contradictory ideas expressed in your first two paragraphs. First you say that SS is not an entitlement but rather an insurance program. Then you say that there should be no means testing, that everyone who paid in is "entitled" to receive benefits. I've been paying life insurance and automobile insurance my whole life and have never received any tangible benefit from either and that makes perfect sense to me. One fervently hopes when taking out any insurance that it will not be needed.

I actually agree with your first statement, that SS should be an insurance program, but that means as with health insurance or life insurance or any other insurance, payment should go only to those who qualify for it and need it. To pay SS dollars to millionaires who don't need it is ridiculous--why would we do that? And your comment that "SS will in any case amount to a small portion of their spending anyway" is irrelevant. It's not senior spending we're concerned about, it is money being allocated to people who don't need it and thus potentially depriving those who do need help.

Social security is not an "entitlement"; it's an insurance program. And there's nothing wrong with the younger generations now paying for the older ones. We should raise the income subject to the payroll tax and then tie it to the rate of inflation or something so that the limit slowly rises. This will keep the system solvent.

No means testing. Everybody who pays in gets the benefit. In retirement, for those who are wealthy and not dependent on Social Security for basic income support, SS will in any case amount to a small portion of their spending anyway and they will continue to pay income taxes.

As for raising the retirement age, that is the wrong way to go. Many people who enjoy work often keep working well past 65 anyway. Modern economies have difficulty providing jobs for all those who want to work. Why should older people be taking jobs that should be made available to the young?
wow... would a phone call from Michelle be enough for you?
Congratulations on your maiden Sunday Tim.

Hmmm... Professor X, X Chromosome, and X-men. Did I mention I finished this up listening to Radiolab's episode on inheritance?

Managed to muddle through a Sunday for the first time which makes me feel like a PRO. Though I admit I'm NOT ABOVE, using Across Lite to check my letters and see what it X's out (Like using X-RAY SPEX though the LEGALISTIC among you will think no better of me than PETE ROSE). The MAINE I thing is ask is; BE NICE TO me--My heart SAURs.

(The more nerdy might note that "X-FACTOR" was a comic book X-tension of the X-MEN. "GENERATION X or GEN x was an Image mutant title as well).
